content: Cricket ground in Singapore The **Padang** or **Singapore Cricket Club Ground** is a cricket ground in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). The Padang became a major [recreational](/wiki/Recreation) area when two clubs, the [Singapore Cricket Club](/wiki/Singapore_Cricket_Club) in 1870 and the [Singapore Recreation Club](/wiki/Singapore_Recreation_Club) in 1883 were established at both ends of the field. It was used for exercising horses in the 1920s and became the scene for the New Year sporting activities. [Cricket](/wiki/Cricket)'s development in the colony took a back seat due to the world wars, However, after [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II) the ground played host to teams such as the touring [Australians](/wiki/Australia_national_cricket_team) of 1959. In 2003 came the club was given the go-ahead to pursue extensive re-development to the cost of $17 million, the first change to its structure for nearly 120 years. Improvements include the appropriately named Stumps bar which boasts an outdoor seating area and views of the ground. Further modernisations have improved the gym and other sporting facilities, In 1996 Padang [Cricket Ground](/wiki/Cricket_field) became the first venue in Singapore to host [One Day International](/wiki/One_Day_International) (ODI's). The first ODI saw [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan_national_cricket_team) play [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka_national_cricket_team) in the [1995â€“96 Singer Cup](/wiki/1995%E2%80%9396_Singer_Cup).
